message_1: What is the heat of crystallization of 50 g of sodium acetate trihydrate (NaC2H3O2.3H2O) when it is dissolved in 200 mL of water at 25°C and then the resulting solution is cooled to 10°C, assuming that no heat is lost to the surroundings? The heat of solution of sodium acetate trihydrate is -4245 J/g.
message_2:
To find the heat of crystallization of sodium acetate trihydrate, we first need to calculate the heat released when it is dissolved in water and then the heat absorbed when the solution is cooled.

1. Heat released during dissolution:
Heat of solution = -4245 J/g
Mass of sodium acetate trihydrate = 50 g

Heat released = Heat of solution × Mass
Heat released = -4245 J/g × 50 g = -212250 J

Since the heat released is negative, it means that the dissolution process is exothermic and releases heat to the surroundings.

2. Heat absorbed during cooling:
We will use the formula q = mcΔT, where q is the heat absorbed, m is the mass of the solution, c is the specific heat capacity of water (4.18 J/g°C), and ΔT is the change in temperature.

First, we need to find the mass of the solution. Assuming the density of the solution is approximately the same as water (1 g/mL), the mass of the water is 200 g. Adding the mass of sodium acetate trihydrate (50 g), the total mass of the solution is 250 g.

ΔT = Final temperature - Initial temperature = 10°C - 25°C = -15°C

Now, we can calculate the heat absorbed:
q = mcΔT
q = (250 g)(4.18 J/g°C)(-15°C) = -15675 J

Since the heat absorbed is negative, it means that the cooling process is endothermic and absorbs heat from the surroundings.

3. Heat of crystallization:
The heat of crystallization is the difference between the heat released during dissolution and the heat absorbed during cooling.

Heat of crystallization = Heat released - Heat absorbed
Heat of crystallization = -212250 J - (-15675 J) = -196575 J

The heat of crystallization of 50 g of sodium acetate trihydrate is -196575 J.
